item.title: 690 æœŸ -
item.description:
title: 690 æœŸ -
editors:

  • Yucohny
    description:

ğŸ”¥ æœ¬å‘¨çƒ­é—¨

How 1Password Used esbuild to Cut Browser Extension Build Times â€”â€” 1Password is a popular password management tool that relies upon a browser extension to fill out passwords on the Web. At over a minute for a single build, things were starting to drag for the devs. Could esbuild help? A fun story with plenty of technical details.

Jarek Samic

Next.js 15 Release Candidate â€”â€” The popular React meta framework gets ready for a major new release with a RC giving you an opportunity to experiment with React 19 (and React Compiler) support, executing code after a response with next/after, and a few potentially breaking changes.

Delba de Oliveira and Zack Tanner

aem1k: A Variety of JS Hacks and Creative Coding â€”â€” This is a fun one. Martin really captures the joy and expressiveness of JavaScript and the Web with his collection of projects, whether itâ€™s offering a NSFW-named tool to convert your JavaScript into just six characters, rendering a spinning globe in 1KB of JS, the Game of Life in 176 bytes, and many more such experiments.

Martin Kleppe

å¿«è®¯ï¼š

  • The folks behind the long standing Gulp build tool are running a survey to help make Gulp better and suit modern needs. It closes tomorrow.

  • ğŸ«  JavaScript's creator Brendan Eich popped up on Twitter/X to refute a claim that JS is "the most slop" by saying it's only 50% so.. I don't get it either.

  • If you haven't gone down the JSR rabbit hole yet, let â–¶ï¸ Ryan Dahl convince you through his DevWorld 2024 talk. (29 minutes.)

  • Three.js introduces its own 'TSL' shader language as a way to write WebGPU shaders with JavaScript rather than the WebGPU Shading Language.

ğŸ“’  æ•™ç¨‹ä¸è¶£äº‹

10 Modern Node.js Runtime Features to Start Using in 2024 â€”â€” If it ever feels like the new feature spotlight shines too much on Bun or Deno, never fear - Node.js has been taking huge strides forward too. Liran looks at lots of whatâ€™s new.

Liran Tal

ECMAScript 2023 Feature: Symbols as WeakMap keys â€”â€” Dr. Axel continues his look at language features by explaining what WeakMaps are for and why using symbols for keys has added benefits.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

â–¶ uBlock Origin: Let's Read the Code â€”â€” A prolific code reader spends some time digging into the popular ad blocker thatâ€™s almost entirely built in JavaScript.

Ants Are Everywhere

Why We Need a Standard JavaScript ORM for SQL Databases â€”â€” ..and is it Drizzle?

Paul Scanlon (The New Stack)

Want Out of React Complexity? Try Vue â€”â€” A high level piece that may provide some context if you havenâ€™t dabbled with Vue yet.

Richard MacManus (The New Stack)

ğŸ“„ Why We Don't Have a Laravel For JavaScript... Yet

Vince Cangerï¼ˆWaspï¼‰

ğŸ“„ Itâ€™s Not Just You, Next.js is Getting Harder to Use

Andrew Israel

ğŸ“„ How to Create a Modal in React with HTML's <dialog>

Colby Fayock

ğŸ“„ What's New in Angular 18

Gergely Szerovay

ğŸ›   ä»£ç ä¸å·¥å…·

Regexper: Display JavaScript Regular Expressions as Railroad Diagrams â€”â€” Might come in handy for learning regular expressions or if you have a complex regular expression and you donâ€™t know what it does (not an uncommon situation..!)

Jeff Avallone

Hono v4.4: The Standards-Based JS Web App Framework for Everywhere â€”â€” Hono is a small, fast web framework with a straightforward API, middleware support, and that runs pretty much on anything (Deno, Bun, Node, Cloudflare, and more). v4.4 brings it to JSR, adds timeout middleware, and a helper to get information about connected clients.

Yusuke Wada and Contributors

Inertia.js v1.1: Build SPAs for Any Backend â€”â€” Inertia acts as â€˜glueâ€™ between various frontend libraries (React, Vue, or Svelte, say) and server-side frameworks (e.g. Rails or Laravel).

Jonathan Reinink

ShareDB v5.0: Realtime Database Backend Based on Operational Transformation â€”â€” For when you need real time synchronization of JSON documents (such as for behind a real time collaboration app).

ShareJS

Qlock: A JavaScript Quine Clock â€”â€” We linked to Martin's array of creative JavaScript experiments earlier, but why not finish with one that particularly tickled us? A quine is a program that takes no input but manages to produce, as output, its own source code. Hereâ€™s a fun JavaScript example that isnâ€™t merely a quine, but a clock too.

Martin Kleppe

ç‰ˆæœ¬å‘å¸ƒï¼š

  • Astro v4.9 â€“ The framework that does everything now does even more, gaining React 19 enhancements, plus a Container API for rendering Astro components outside of Astro apps.

  • Rspack v0.7 â€“ Fast Rust-based web bundler.

  • Storybook v8.1 â€“ The frontend component workshop.

  • Deno v1.44

  • PyMiniRacer v0.12.2 â€“ Call your Python from your JavaScript from your Python.

  • Knip v5.17.0 â€“ Finds and removes unused files, dependencies and exports. Now with more.

  • PM2 v5.4 â€“ Popular Node.js-based process manager for production.

  • Melange v4.0 â€“ OCaml compiler for JavaScript developers.

  • Neutralinojs v5.2 â€“ Lightweight cross-platform desktop app framework.

  • Billboard.js v3.12 â€“ The popular chart library gets funnel charts.

  • Peaks.js v3.4 â€“ BBC-created audio waveform UI component.

  • Happy DOM v14.12 â€“ JS implementation of a web browser sans UI.

  • Retire.js v5.0 â€“ Scans for JS libraries with known vulnerabilities.

  • React Native Boilerplate v4.2 â€“ A starter template for RN apps.

  • RE:DOM v4.1 â€“ Tiny library for creating user interfaces.

  • AlaSQL.js v4.4 â€“ Isomorphic JavaScript SQL database.

  • is-what v5.0 â€“ Simple, small JS type check functions.

  • FxTS v1.0 â€“ Functional programming library.
